Elden Ring was my first Souls game. And I think most people agree that Elden Ring is one of the easier entry of this type of games. But Sekiro caught my eye, due to it being the hardest Souls-like game (according to others). And indeed it was hard. I was stuck at the first major boss for a whole week, and I'd attempt to fight him at least an hour or two a day. But after that, everything just got easier. Of course another boss made me quit the game for a while but I came back and beat him, and at the end I managed to beat the final boss only after 11 tries.

Story wise it isn't that strong, but I still find it interesting nonetheless. Combat is top notch and feels so smooth and satisfying. The game feels fair 95% of the time, although there is an optional boss that kinda throws away everything you've learnt so you have to improvise when fighting him. While in other Souls game you can cheese bosses or get overleveled and a super broken weapon to beat them, in this game you can't do all that. You actually need to get good and at least learn the moveset. I did cheese one of the bosses but that still requires you to look at his moveset and time your attacks. At the end it took me around 10-15 minutes to cheese him. If you're willing to learn and willing to be patient, this game will feel so rewarding.

Again I went from the easiest Souls-like to the hardest entry with no experience. And if I can beat this game, so can you.

Sekiro is one of my favourite games ever. The combat, music, environments, lore, characters; everything is absolutely incredible from top to bottom. I've played through it multiple times and 100%'d it years ago, but I still come back periodically just to replay some of the boss fights and I'm always impressed with just how much I remember from pure muscle memory alone. 

I've seen some people call Sekiro a rhythm game, owing to how you sometimes wait for the enemy to attack to deflect, but I have to admit that's only half the battle. The game actively rewards you for putting pressure on the enemies with the posture system. Enemies can deflect and counter just like the player, making the combat feel more like the enemies react to your moves rather than simply dishing out their attacks in the same pattern every time you fight them. Even bosses react if you manage to cut off their combos with an attack of your own, or even move out of the way; [spoiler] Genichiro, for example, can be caught off guard and stumble backwards trying to block if you attack him after his jumping spin slash, just before he does his backhand grab. If you also move away during his big combo, Floating Passage, he'll actually adapt mid-combo and chase you down with his bow instead. [/spoiler] Many of the bosses even follow up on their combos differently depending on if you deflect, block, Mikiri Counter or even jump counter their final attack. It's honestly really hard to put into words how cool I think it is that enemies react so varyingly just by how YOU react. 

Compared to its Souls cousins, the game is far more linear and personal with its story, and if you expect more than some minor variation of katana combat, you'll probably be disappointed expecting something as diverse as Dark Souls or Elden Ring. Despite that, the Combat Arts the game gives you are each extremely cool and add some extra spice. I still would've liked some kind of hotbar or selection wheel to switch between these mid-combat instead of having to go to the menu to switch them out. 

Sekiro also doesn't overstay its welcome, being just concise enough to have every location be relevant while also being expansive enough to reward you for exploring them thoroughly with cool items and even new prosthetic tools and NPCs (we love you Kotaro). You do however revisit some of the locations, but the game manages to freshen them up to make it interesting still. I also can't overstate how cool the music is, Yuka Kitamura absolutely killed it. 

I honestly could go on and on about how much I love this game, but I feel like it would just be a wall of text, more than the one I've already written. All in all I obviously recommend you get the game. There's a good reason why this game won GOTY, even while developed alongside the much bigger Elden Ring (which also won GOTY 3 years later).

[b] TLDR:  7.5/10. Extremely good game with a refreshing combat system and phenomenal voice acting to carry it's decent plot. Definitely recommend after you play games like Khazan and Lies of P to get used to the Souls-genre! [/b]

BREAKDOWN:

[b] Visuals: 8/10 [/b]

For 2019 standards, this game looks phenomenal. I especially love the fire and palace sequences, where it almost looks lifelike. The only reason why it doesn't get a perfect score is because some of the cutscenes are not quite up to par and it's lacking a bit of visual diversity in terms of settings it could've explored.

[b] Plot: 6/10 [/b]

While not the game's strongest point, it's a small, intimate and compelling story that is marred by FromSoft's idiotic way of storytelling. I don't understand their overreliance on having you read through text from items to understand what's going on around the world and expect you to remember everything during the entirety of the playthrough. I am one of the many who didn't understand what the HELL was going on during the final battle "twist". Alas, compared to the clusterfuck that was Elden Ring, this one was much easier to understand and appreciate.

[b] Character Arcs: 8/10 [/b]

Much of the game's good plot is carried by the very compelling character arcs that unfold. The game treats it's characters in a very mature light and all of their respective arcs feel VERY deserved towards the end of the game.

[b] Voice Acting: 10/10 [/b]

The best part about the game, hands down. The voice acting carried the plot in my opinion!

[b] Combat: 9/10 [/b]

Out of all the Souls-game I've played so far, this is my favorite combat experience by far! Having the posture bar be much prominent in fights than the health bar makes it an extremely immersive "samurai showdown", because you can't run away and heal without the enemy essentially "gaining back their health." I would've given it a perfect score if not for the fact the game feels a little bit too reliant on the parry mechanic and doesn't have any much in the terms of combat versatility.

[b] Open World: 6/10 [/b]

The open world is vast, albeit a bit sparse in content, which I found a tad bit disappointing. The side quests are largely what brings the score up here, because I thought they were fun and added much texture to the main story.

[b] Music: 8/10 [/b]

The music is overall excellent and extremely high-octane, which serves it very well in the boss fights. However, one gripe I have with it is that the music that plays during mob encounters is quite frustrating to hear after the 50th time and I wish there would've been more diversity in that aspect.

[b] Progression & Systems: 8/10 [/b]

This game's progression and power curve is almost flawlessly handled and the skill tree feels very impactful to put points into. The only small gripe is that some of the master skills take a little bit too long to farm up and aren't that useful, which sort of makes the time investment of grinding to them feel pretty bad. Additionally, I found the ability to pause between boss fights kind of janky as well.

[b] Grindiness: 5/10 [/b]

For a FromSoft game, this game is surprisingly not too grindy. It's still annoying that this game feels very inaccessible without external content helping you out, but it's much better than the abomination that is Elden Ring.

[b] Enjoyability: 9/10 [/b]

Looking back on my month long journey playing this game, I was extremely surprised by the polish and the fluidity of the combat mechanics of this game, it's truly revolutionary for its time. The beautifully designed combat system with the compact, intimate plot and the incredible voice acting make this game an absolute treasure to play and I look forward to coming back to this game in a few years time to relive this experience again!

[b] Bonus: [/b]

[b] Boss Recycling: -3 [/b]

Even though it pains me to do this, I feel like it wouldn't be fair to take some points off for some major bosses either being recycled or just straight up showing up again without changing much. This game is seriously close to lacking some real boss versatility, but it's saved by the grandeur and impact of it's best bosses.

[b] TOTAL: 74/100 [/b]

Best game I've played. It was very hard for me, being my first souls-like ever. I had to take pages of notes on all the bosses, watch videos of others doing the fights, and memorize the enemy combos and different attacks and how I needed to react to it. You should go into each fight being okay with dying, and view each attempt as a learning experience. It will test your patience, skill, and ability to be strategic and plan how you'll approach the fight, and it's great to watch yourself improve as you keep practicing. By now I've got 100%, I've done all the gauntlets and am on New Game +4, and beating it after struggling is very satisfying.

 If you're stuck on a boss, go to bed and let your brain rest and encode what you learned about that boss today, then try again the next day. You will probably realize you did learn a lot by sleeping on it, and will be performing much better. This isn't really a game you can play when you're tired, hungry, sleep deprived, or in any sub-optimal state like that, you need to be rested, be very alert, have good reaction times, etc. One of the most important things in order to do well in these boss fights is to remain calm and not panic. The more calm and composed you are, the easier it is to deflect properly and react in the best way to each attack.

The art style and graphics are amazing, and you frequently come across beautiful views of mountain ranges, giant cliffs, and vividly colored trees and leaves. While the combat is clearly the star of this game and what it's known for, the story is also good, and I've grown to appreciate the story more on repeated game cycles, now that I'm comfortable with the fights.

You may have to plan on restarting with a new game several times unless you are a natural speedster. Also, if you die, you have to do the entire area over. Bad stuff: 60 fps locked in current year. If a mod can easily bypass this, then this can be added by devs. For me this is enough of a dealbreaker on its own. The option menu is abysmal, and although performance is not as atrocious as Elden Ring, it's unacceptable for a game that looks as this one does.

Posture system is a neat idea but in reality it doesn't. Your own posture barely matters, most enemies can't punish a posture break and it takes less than 2 seconds to recover by just holding block. On bosses it matters but not as much as damage. You can kill a boss by depleting the posture, but for posture to not deplete fast, you need to deal damage first. So it ends up feeling like posture damage doesn't matter for a good chunk of the fight, and then damage doesn't matter. I get the idea but it's badly executed.

Farming is waaaay too encouraged. If you have a ton of experience you are encouraged to farm till your next level or you risk too much if you die. Gold pouches seem like a system that only feels bad. You don't feel smart for paying the 10% tax to save your gold, losing it feels bad, using the pouches feels bad. It's not like gold is super necessary, it's just there to make you feel bad about dying. More than a soulslike. XP tree is bloated with things just to encourage farming. Shinobi tool upgrades require a ton of materials that are rare drops on specific mobs. There are literally consumables to help you farm. Why not like, remove this entirely from the game? It adds nothing and makes everything feel worse. You even have to farm your revives, so you'll be attempting a boss, you don't have your 2/3 revives, you need to go out, kill some trash to farm your revives, to go back to the boss and lose the xp and gold you gathered while farming.

Which gets us to the next point. The trial and error is replaced by a easier game where you are punished a lot for failing. Consumables are super op, tools are op, revives are op, you get too much healing. For me there's just too many frustrating issues with this game.

___GAMEPLAY____

First off, there's very little choice in how you engage with the combat or the world. It's one of the most linear games I've played in a long while. 

How the game GENERALLY work is as follows, you, the player, will enter an area, where there's a set number of enemies, you can't really attack multiple enemies at once, since they'll just gang up on you immediately, so 1-on-1 is definitely preferred, occasionally you can deal a couple of the weaker enemies at the same time, but generally you definitely want to sneak around and stealth kill.

The stealth is half baked and feels on rails, sometimes enemies can spot you a mile away and run ALL the way to you, other times you can shank a friend of theirs 5 meters to their right and they'd be none the wiser. It really depends on if you stealth kill the enemies in the correct sequence. This can be a very lengthy process and you're gonna do this A LOT in each area.

The combat is too much waiting and either parry/jump/dodge (except dodge is super nerfed in this game) depending on the attack animation. You have very little agency in controlling the battles you are almost only reacting and never acting, it's like one long randomized QTE you have to endure. This is to the point where the miniboss battles I did endure to beat was not enjoyable or fun but just a chore. 

Miniboss? you ask, why yes, there's two kinds of hard enemies, afaik, minibosses and then regular bosses, the regular bosses will give you a small boost to your attack stat (btw, there's no allocation of rpg stats in this game, so forget about "builds") now minibosses are probably gonna take up most of your time, they're basically very difficult enemies with a series of attack patterns that you need to learn 100% or else you'll just die. Mostly you need to learn to deflect when the correct animation plays (which is the vast, VAST majority of combat) to the point it feels like you're playing a rhythm game.

Now a lot of the combat is supposed to be about reading the animation and reacting accordingly, but do you know what's constantly blocking the camera from clearly seeing the enemy that you're up close to? that's right the player character itself. Then there's the camera who will spazz out when you're in tight corners. and sometimes just not lock on to the enemy RIGHT NEXT to you, and in an easier game I could forgive that, totally, but not when the punishment for death is as high as it is. 

Whenever you die, and you will die, a lot, you lose half your money and a lump portion of xp, which can't be retrieved, it's just gone. Then there's the dragonrot where if you die enough times, which you will, npcs will stop helping you, so you have to spend extra money to fix it in order to progress a story line.

____STORY AND LORE____

Then there's the story and lore, I do think there's something interesting about this world and how so many of it's inhabitants are obsessed with immortality, especially the undead monks, were really cool.

But I don't care about the main character and his lord (a twelve year old boy with magic resurrection blood), really none of the characters are of any interest to me, except maybe the Carver and the undead training dummy, they're kindda funny. 

____Overall____
And that's really the issues I have overall with the game, I'm not interested in getting better in a game, that I have so little stake in. I don't care about the characters or what's gonna happen next to them, the world itself is kindda cool, but not enough to warrant the ungodly amount of hours I'd have to invest in order to "git gud".

Let's get one thing out of the way first: [b]This game isn't a souls-like[/b], it's its own thing that borrows *some* aspects of FromSoft's other games. There's no co-op, no "builds", and your only variety in "weapons" comes from the different prosthetics you can unlock, which can serve offensive, defensive, or utility purposes. If you come into this expecting a souls-like, you're likely going to be just as disappointed as I was.

This game focuses on a very narrow set of skills, and it expects you refine them to a fairly high degree of mastery. You'll be performing more or less the same sets of moves for a majority of the game's run time, barring a few skills thrown in here and there for spice, and bosses don't generally do anything crazy that breaks the "rules" you learn fairly early on (bear in mind, at time of writing I still haven't seen the last three non-optional bosses of the normal route). Every boss very much has an "intended" way of being fought, although with sufficient skill and/or practice you can work other strategies as well. If that sounds appealing to you, ignore the red thumbs down and give it a try.

Each enemy very much has their own unique rhythm to them, and even the strongest opponents eventually becomes a matter of going through motions like clockwork, meaning the fights will play out more or less the same, depending on movepool rng. Personally, I just found that this meant that once I "mastered" a certain enemy, combat in that area became incredibly boring. This is eased somewhat by using stealth to avoid or eliminate enemies outside of combat, but many stronger enemies are purposefully placed in ways that make them difficult to stealth kill. This also becomes a problem with the many (mostly optional) mini-bosses you'll encounter across the maps, almost all of which are recycled at least once. Simply put: if the combat doesn't "click" with you, it's going to get repetitive and tedious very quickly.

Moving on to the areas themselves, I personally found them much less visually interesting than the usual FromSoft fare. There are some lovely views in the more mountainous areas, but nothing that really awed me or made me sit and stare for a while. The layout of the areas also feels much more obviously video game-y, especially with the way the grappling hook points are almost always lined up to perfectly direct you towards you current objective. The levels are much more open and vertical than other pre-Elden Ring FromSoft games, but it's marred by the subpar platforming. Disappointed as I am in this game, I'll not say one ill word about Sekiro's combat mechanics. It functions entirely as intended and has a good weight to it. The platforming though? Atrocious. Wolf's jumps are incredibly float and just feel bad. The "green" zone for grappling hooks also feels oddly inconsistent, especially for the ones that slingshot you instead of bringing you to a new platform, since it's possible to be on the "wrong side" of it without any way of knowing. Ultimately, though, if you're just going in to the game for combat alone, these are minor annoyances.

Finally, I'll touch on the bosses. The bosses are the part of this game that confuse me the most. Clearly, the main draw for this title is the combat, and the combat in this game works best when you're having an uninterrupted 1v1, so bosses should be where it shines the most, right? Yes and no. There are some bosses that definitely demonstrate a more intricate and compelling dance of combat, like Owl, Corrupted Monk, and Lady Butterfly, but there are others like Guardian Ape that suddenly turn away from the strengths of the combat. And you have to fight him twice, unless you do Corrupted Monk first. Moreover, some bosses (but moreso the mini-bosses) tend to have gimmicks that are countered by consumables. These range from just being convenient time-savers (using snap seeds to dispells Lady Butterflies illusions immediately) to significantly altering the difficulty of the fight (using divine confetti and the purple gourd against any Headless miniboss). Often times, these bosses appear before those consumables are easily accessible, which means its possible to fail to kill the boss in the first few tries and then be left at a disadvantagous in subsequent attempts. BUT, I will say that most of the unique interactions are either completely spelled out for you, or are at least obvious if you take the time to read what your consumables actually do.

I'll probably still finish the game, out of stubbornness if nothing else, but I definitely feel underwhelmed after all the massive hype I constantly hear about the game, so I'll leave that as the lesson for this review: regardless of if you agree with me or not or end up liking the game or not, don't just immediately buy into a game because it's well regarded and well liked. Do you research, try to dig into what people are actually saying, and make sure it's money well spent.

Not every FromSoftware game is the same and this one isn't for me.

The biggest problem by far is how the fundamental idea of combat based engagement doesn't align well with the mechanics of the world.
 Example A: 1v1 combat and stealth are the primary forms of engagement. Yet the environment makes it so most major 1v1 fights are accompanied by multiple enemies or the environments themselves are designed to only hinder the player, such as with General Kuranosuke Matsumoto and his four rifle men or Lone Shadow Swordsmen and a space so narrow my camera becomes the biggest threat. 
  Because of this, setting the stage for a 1v1 fight is a chore. Meanwhile stealth becomes an afterthought used to avoid combat or cheese 1 deathblow out of a mini-boss (which these opponents seriously do not need 2 of).  

Example B: The tools and skills of which can be unlocked through exploration and killing mobs result in a lot of tools that have little to no pay out, specifically against bosses. This is because bosses tend to have the standard FromSoftware -High Mobility -One Hit Kills -Insane HP -Variable Moves, but now in addition to those they also gain -Insane Poise. This means you have to do a full boss fights worth of HP damage before any poise damage connects (which is how you deal deathblows), so moves like Mikiri Counter have zero effect while Tools like Loaded Spear do little to no damage. Which means Sekiro is more of an Intrinsic skill game and less of an Extrinsic skill game. Sen (money), Skills and Items are the only things a player can farm on mobs, and these will gain no favor over the battles that need to be fought. The only way to gain real Extrinsic power is by already having beat the enemies you originally needed the power for.  Bosses give strength (damage) and Mini-bosses give Beads which become more HP. 

So you have the usual FromSoftware cycle of live-die-repeat, except Hidetaka Miyazaki thought it would be really cute if the more you die the harder the game gets. Thanks to Dragon Aids, every time you die it gives way for NPC's to get sick. This causes any quests with an NPC to close, and it also causes Unseen Aid to lower. In Sekiro you can't recollect your dropped 'souls' on death, but you have a % chance to lose nothing on death with Unseen Aid, which is percentage based on current NPC's. The reasoning behind this Dragon Aid's spread is explained a bit in game but it doesn't make any sense why it would spread only to friendly NPC's but not any of the other endless enemies you engage with in the world. It's a very spiteful form of Aids I guess and an even shittier mechanic.

Ultimately, it feels like FromSoftware had an IDEA for a more technical based combat system in one of their worlds. Separate and far more linear than the mixed-pot form of their other games. However the cohesion between the standard FromSoftware world and the new combat system just isn't there.

For me there's just too many frustrating issues with this game.

___GAMEPLAY____

First off, there's very little choice in how you engage with the combat or the world. It's one of the most linear games I've played in a long while. 

How the game GENERALLY work is as follows, you, the player, will enter an area, where there's a set number of enemies, you can't really attack multiple enemies at once, since they'll just gang up on you immediately, so 1-on-1 is definitely preferred, occasionally you can deal a couple of the weaker enemies at the same time, but generally you definitely want to sneak around and stealth kill.

The stealth is half baked and feels on rails, sometimes enemies can spot you a mile away and run ALL the way to you, other times you can shank a friend of theirs 5 meters to their right and they'd be none the wiser. It really depends on if you stealth kill the enemies in the correct sequence. This can be a very lengthy process and you're gonna do this A LOT in each area.

The combat is too much waiting and either parry/jump/dodge (except dodge is super nerfed in this game) depending on the attack animation. You have very little agency in controlling the battles you are almost only reacting and never acting, it's like one long randomized QTE you have to endure. This is to the point where the miniboss battles I did endure to beat was not enjoyable or fun but just a chore. 

Miniboss? you ask, why yes, there's two kinds of hard enemies, afaik, minibosses and then regular bosses, the regular bosses will give you a small boost to your attack stat (btw, there's no allocation of rpg stats in this game, so forget about "builds") now minibosses are probably gonna take up most of your time, they're basically very difficult enemies with a series of attack patterns that you need to learn 100% or else you'll just die. Mostly you need to learn to deflect when the correct animation plays (which is the vast, VAST majority of combat) to the point it feels like you're playing a rhythm game.

Now a lot of the combat is supposed to be about reading the animation and reacting accordingly, but do you know what's constantly blocking the camera from clearly seeing the enemy that you're up close to? that's right the player character itself. Then there's the camera who will spazz out when you're in tight corners. and sometimes just not lock on to the enemy RIGHT NEXT to you, and in an easier game I could forgive that, totally, but not when the punishment for death is as high as it is. 

Whenever you die, and you will die, a lot, you lose half your money and a lump portion of xp, which can't be retrieved, it's just gone. Then there's the dragonrot where if you die enough times, which you will, npcs will stop helping you, so you have to spend extra money to fix it in order to progress a story line.

____STORY AND LORE____

Then there's the story and lore, I do think there's something interesting about this world and how so many of it's inhabitants are obsessed with immortality, especially the undead monks, were really cool.

But I don't care about the main character and his lord (a twelve year old boy with magic resurrection blood), really none of the characters are of any interest to me, except maybe the Carver and the undead training dummy, they're kindda funny. 

____Overall____
And that's really the issues I have overall with the game, I'm not interested in getting better in a game, that I have so little stake in. I don't care about the characters or what's gonna happen next to them, the world itself is kindda cool, but not enough to warrant the ungodly amount of hours I'd have to invest in order to "git gud".
